text: Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen so the holiday season  is approaching us again and around this time i

usually get questions how can i incorporate some 
thai flavors into the holiday table and there

really isn't like thai dishes that's specific 
to the holidays we just eat whatever whenever

so i thought i would do a mashup of thai flavors 
with a traditional holiday dish namely pumpkin pie

so i thought that you know there is a thai dessert 
called kanom maw gaeng which is conceptually very

similar to a pumpkin pie in that it is a custard 
and it usually has some mashed vegetable in it

like taro or mung beans so i thought i wonder if 
it will work with pumpkin instead and then baked

into a form of a pumpkin pie so i tried it out and 
my gosh it works so incredibly well i'm so happy

to share this with you and it's really really easy 
all right let's get started so we're not gonna go

over how to make pie crust in this video because 
one that's not really the point two i already

have a pie crust video which i will link to it's a 
really easy one that you can use with this recipe

and three you can use this filling with 
any kind of pie crust that you already know

how to make even store-bought ones would 
work so i have one here that i have made

formed chilled and docked with a fork to prevent 
it from puffing up and what we need to do first is

blind bake it which means par baking the pie 
crust so that it's half cooked before i put

the filling in before i do that i need to fill it 
with something heavy so that when you bake it it

doesn't shrink back so what i have here is a piece 
of parchment paper which i'm going to crumble up

i do this so that it will form a little bit more 
easily to the shape of the pie and i put that in

here okay so now you can weigh down with rice 
beans or they sell ceramic pie plates if you

bake a lot but i've discovered that you can also 
use sugar because you can just reuse this sugar

and whatever if you use rice or beans you can't 
cook that anymore it's not it's not good and this

just helps weigh down the crust this is going to 
go into a 375 degree oven for about 20 minutes

until the edges look cooked but not yet browned 
oh and bottom rack alright so while that's

doing its thing let's make the filling so 
the thing that's gonna make this filling thai

is coconut palm sugar and pandan leaf surprise not 
really super classic thai dessert ingredients so

i'm going to add some coconut milk into this pot 
here and then what i'll do is i'll reduce this by

half because i want to get as much coconut flavor 
in as i can without all the liquid which will make

the pie too runny so i'm going to reduce this 
by half while that's going we're also going to

add pandan leaves to infuse the pandan leaves huh 
today i've got a whole fresh bouquet to show you

usually i use them frozen but i just managed 
to get some fresh ones these are pandan leaves

and it's our version of vanilla basically 
it's the aromatic herb that we add into so

many desserts just about every dessert have some 
sort of like a pandan leaf if you don't have it

you can substitute vanilla i suppose it's not 
gonna be the same you can buy pandan extracts

as well which is not as good so if you can find 
find the actual leaf i'm gonna just cut this into

little chunks and as the coconut milk is 
reducing it will just infuse the flavor

into our mixture get that submerged and so this 
will go for about 10 minutes and then i do want

it to be reduced exactly by half okay so i think 
that's about half i'm not sure so what we have

to do and you really want to do this this is 
not something you want to eyeball you want to

measure how much coconut milk you have left if 
you have a little bit less it's not a big deal

but if you have too much then your filling will 
be too wet and it's not going to set up okay so

this is quite important so i'm just going to pour 
it back into the measuring cup that i used earlier

perfect and then also the pandan leaves they are 
done so you don't need that anymore that can go

pour that back in and now you can see it's 
like super thick and luscious okay so now

we're gonna just flavor this with 
some salt very very important

because we're all about balancing the sweetness 
right so stir that until it's dissolved and then

canned pumpkin so i'm gonna stick to tradition by 
using this good old store-bought canned pumpkin

puree here so that goes straight in and it'll 
help cool down our coconut milk too so with

this off heat now i'm just using the pot as 
a mixing bowl at this point i'm just gonna

give this a good mix cool it down before i add 
my egg so i don't make pumpkin scrambled eggs

now i have i see just some streaks of unevenness

in the in this recipe they make great christmas

stuffers so i have turned the oven down to 350 
after i've baked the crust and now this is going

to go and bake for about an hour give or take 
five minutes depending on your oven or how cold or

warm the filling is going in but it's gonna take 
quite a bit of time so i'll see you then it looks

amazing it should sort of jiggle a little in the 
middle it shouldn't look like it's completely

liquid inside obviously but it does have a bit of 
a jiggle and that's totally fine if you have an

instant read thermometer which i highly recommend 
that you use um you can stick it smack in the

middle and the temperature you're going for is 
170 degrees fahrenheit usually that's what i do

at home but i forgot to bring it i should just 
leave one here and then the benefit of using

glass pie plate is you can also look in the bottom 
to see whether it's golden which it should be

hot but you know if it's not quite golden enough 
it's still a little bit soggy you can stick it

back in the oven for a little bit you have to wait 
for i would say at least two hours so at least

until it comes to room temperature before cutting 
into it because right now it's too soft to warm it

will deflate a little bit totally normal it might 
even crack a little bit once it's deflated totally

normal don't worry about it we're gonna cover it 
up with some garnishes on top anyway i should also

point out that you should absolutely put the 
pie on a sheet pan in the oven don't just put

the pie directly on the rack because especially 
if you have a really buttery crust that comes

around the edges some butter will melt and 
sort of overflow out onto the sheet pan as you

can see here i've got some melted butter here 
this crust recipe has so much butter in it so

there's a lot of butter if you're using different 
recipe with less butter this may not happen

but it's always safe to put it on a sheet pan so 
while the oven is still hot from the pie don't

turn it off quite yet i'm going to toast some 
coconut to go on top now you don't have to use

this shape of coconut so i'm using like these big 
flakes but i feel like this shape is the prettiest

but you can like do top it with nuts or you know 
or extra pie crust that you cut and put on top but

i really feel like the coconut flavor in the pie 
is well accentuated by the flavor of the coconut

so from a flavor standpoint i really recommend 
coconut and we're going to toast it quite dark

just in the same oven at 350 that it was 
before and it will take just a few minutes nice

yeah that's the smell i'm going for and this may 
be a little darker than some of you are familiar

with i feel like in western baking they like to do 
these light blunt coconut no but you want to toast

it a little bit darker you can even go a touch 
darker than this to really get that toasted flavor

and when you smell it you'll be like okay that's 
what we're talking about so now i'm just gonna let

this cool sprinkle it on top of the pie oh by the 
way i forgot to mention my little donut trick here

for things like this where they brown easily if 
you make a hole in the middle it'll help it cook

evenly because usually it's the patch in the 
middle that's less cooked than the other part

this way you don't have to go back and 
stir it and there's my oven going off
